text: I loved volunteering with you!!!

I have a whole new level of respect and admiration for those who host and organize scientific conferences. @ recomb2019 was hectic but great, especially being alongside @ BeccasBugs 24/7! # recomb2019 pic.twitter.com/4NCnGrWQN9
@ LorenzoDiTucci

Hope everyone enjoyed # recomb2019! Thank you for traveling to Washington, DC. We look forward to seeing you all again at # recomb2020, which will be in Italy during the first two weeks of May (exact 6-day period will be available later)!

Huge thanks to all the volunteers for the main # recomb2019 conference! Your assistance, enthusiasm, and humor helped to make RECOMB amazing! Hope to see all of you at future RECOMB conferences. pic.twitter.com/7LceMNwFTT
Slides from the @ NSF and @ NIH panels at # recomb2019 are available online under the Materials page. https://recomb2019.org/materials/
Big thanks to all the chairs for # recomb2019: Mona Sighn, @ nomad421, Lenore Cowen, and all the PC committee members!
@ recomb2019 thanks for the wonderful learning experience. Here are some beautiful shots from the cruise! pic.twitter.com/G0DFjEUQhO
Thanks Gurkan!
Well deserved. I thought the presentation and work was great.
Thanks @ recomb2019 (cc @ sanchit_misra )https://twitter.com/recomb2019/status/1126261153527734272 …

I was so happy to see @ EmilyEAckerman at # recomb2019. She was in my computational genomics class last year at CMU and she always had great questions. She was named one of the 45 HHMI Gilliam Fellows in the nation last year. She is amazing! https://twitter.com/EmilyEAckerman/status/1125479798070030336 …

Congratulations to Rohit Singh, Jinbo Xu and Bonnie Berger for being the # recomb2019 test of time award winners! Their paper was the most influential paper published at RECOMB 2007 in Oakland, CA! pic.twitter.com/putLdCp8ju
The # recomb2019 best paper award goes to Martin Zhang, Fei Xia and James Zou! Thanks @ SpringerNature for your support!pic.twitter.com/PsArautucu

Shout-out to the organizers and speakers of @ recomb2019 ! Great conference, interesting talks, fantastic people! Looking forward to a few more days in the US before heading home. # GWUpic.twitter.com/FYovLwNkbO

Excited to share that our AdaFDR paper on covariate-adaptive multiple testing (https://www.biorxiv.org/content/10.1101/496372v1 …), joint work with @ xf1280 and Prof. James Zou, has won the best paper award at @ recomb2019 pic.twitter.com/z9DLDSjRJn
Flying back to @ UCBerkeley after # recomb2019. Thanks all for the interesting talks and for being such a great community! @ recomb2019 pic.twitter.com/2gikRLe6Fq
Really enjoying my first Recomb conference! Lots of wonderful speakers and algorithms. # recomb2019

Great, thanks!
My slides are online if anyone wants to see what they missed! https://doi.org/10.6084/m9.figshare.8094830 …
“Similarity is not enough” -Metin Balaban on phylogenetic placement # recomb2019

Work from @ VingronLab on a new take on graphical models allowing for non-linear associations between nodes using empirical distance covariance presented by Martin Vingron @ recomb2019 - going from N to N^2 - exciting work for all us # networkinference guys!
Another great talk @ recomb2019

Temporal Pathway Synthesizer - extract sign directed networks from longitudinal protein phosphorylation data to study EGF signaling (and other pathways) - work presented by @ anthonygitter - @ recomb2019 # TPS # MassSpec
Great to see the Korean genome was useful :)
Hoping new friends I met at # recomb2019 will be interested!

Working towards reference-free transcriptome reconstruction with isONclust. Cool stuff from Kristoffer Sahlin @ krsahlin # recomb2019

Fatemah Almodaresi just gave great talk on: “An Efficient and Scalable Representation of High-Dimensional Color Information Enabled via de Bruijn Graph Search”. Scales up to thousands of samples via new min spanning tree color representation: https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/978-3-030-17083-7_1 … # recomb2019
Fatemeh ( @ fataltes) presenting our work on compressing color information in the colored de Bruijn Graph at # RECOMB2019 (work with @ prashn_25)!pic.twitter.com/ZwMfe0fOiS

Why reference free? Because 1. many genomes do not have a reference assembly 2. some gene families are not well represented in model organisms -- we keep finding novel genomic and perhaps transcriptomic sequences (poster and talk at # recomb2019 by Rachel Sherman et al)
I will be giving a talk about clustering long transcriptomic reads into gene families in the next # recomb2019 sequencing track (https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/978-3-030-17083-7_14 …)

Cool: Philipp Benner from @ VingronLab presents his hidden Markov model @ recomb2019 for identifying genome-wide chromatin states and capturing spatial distributions of chromatin patterns - HMM still seem to be popular in Genome Organization research (see # phyloHMRF before) # modHMM
Yang Yang in my group did fantastic job presenting her paper at # RECOMB2019. I’m immensely proud of her work! @ CMUCompBio @ recomb2019 @ SCSatCMUpic.twitter.com/BjJjIhG5OA
Additionally, volunteers will be leaving at 5/10 minute increments between 5:10 and 5:45 to help participants travel from Lisner to Spirit of Mt Vernon. # RECOMB2019

If you are planning on taking the metro to get to the social event at Spirit of Mt Vernon, here are two options for taking the metro from Foggy Bottom to there. A metro card is needed to ride. There are paper copies of these directions at the registration desk! # RECOMB2019 pic.twitter.com/9ztccH0HJR

How to compare Hi-C contact maps on a continuous scale across species? Maybe use a phylogenetic HMRF model to infer evolutionary patters from HiC matrices - work presented by Yang Yang from Carnegie Mellon University @ recomb2019 preprint: https://www.biorxiv.org/content/10.1101/552505v1 … # phyloHMRF

Rui Quiao from University of Waterloo reports his work on de-novo peptide sequencing from data independent acquisition MS data using Deep Neural Networks - identify novel and low abundance peptides using # DeepNovo @ recomb2019 : https://www.nature.com/articles/s41592-018-0260-3 …
Missing @ calkan_cs and @ DavisCompGen and other Cenk’s current and former lab members # recomb2019 hopefully in # recomb2020 in Italy!pic.twitter.com/GD8HuZVXhj

Special Panel Session on # Genomic # Privacy # recomb2019. “The individual should be at the center of the # control of their # data.” @ cdbustamante As “with great power comes great responsability”, companies should be ready to face “regulations” & “fines” when they do not meet them.pic.twitter.com/lkbWvEa71u – bei Lisner Auditorium
@ cdbustamante : “For younger generations, the data stream they generate is the most valuable asset they have. They deserve control over it” @ recomb2019 # RECOMB19 pic.twitter.com/HewHwTrwkI

Secret sharing has applications to drug discovery using private pharmacological data. Hyunghoon Cho @ Hoon_Cho # recomb2019

Two speakers presenting their work at # recomb2019 is a sign of an important topic! Kockan and Zhu describe how multiple institutions can share human genomic data in a secure and privacy-preserving manner. # VCF # privacyingenomics # SNP # analysis # intel # SGX # data # genomicmedicinepic.twitter.com/k89aDLsBmf – bei Lisner Auditorium
With the rate of the coverage and DNA uploads in 3rd party websites, in future, this will be the case for any open database # RECOMB2019 pic.twitter.com/OmYAAjrDis

@ cdbustamante : “Academia is the alternative career. We should tell our students that” # RECOMB2019 pic.twitter.com/qIvvLEQSZ2
Methods are tactical, data is strategic. @ cdbustamante on the new era of precision medicine @ recomb2019.

@ cdbustamante talking about problems in effectively delivering health care to the patient and 'data being the new oil' for tech companies @ recomb2019 - inspiring key-note and refreshing take on big data in health care! # gwu # health # PatientCare # fh
Health data is already on our phones - so how we want that data to be used? Carlos Bustamante # recomb2019
“Data is the new toxic waste. If you let it leak, you’re in trouble! “ @ cdbustamante # RECOMB2019
“Effective heath care delivery is a data supply chain problem” Carlos Bustamante on PCSK9 inhibitors and precision medicine # recomb2019
Carlos bustamante @ cdbustamante: to give you an idea how the genomics is scaling up, in 2018, Illumina sequenced/genotyped 10 times more data as Netflix did with its catalogue # RECOMB2019
CB: last year @ illumina produced 10 times more data than Netflix catalog. @ cdbustamante # recomb2019

We still have very little representation of non-Europeans in the genomes of the world" says @ cdbustamante at # RECOMB2019. I recall clearly he was also a recomb keynote at # recomb2009 in Arizona (10 years ago!) where he showed his famous PCA plot. I asked this question back then!"
Carlos Bustamante @ cdbustamante is sharing his vision to get genomic-based health care cheaper, better and faster and talks about what needs to be done # RECOMB2019 pic.twitter.com/aTyWIkO7ay

DNA # shotgun # sequencing can produce a tremendous amount of data from clinical samples. Accurate, precise, fast, scalable and secure methods are needed for analyzing these data. Come check out my poster 83 presenting some # research work on # privacy in # metagenomics. # recomb2019 – bei Marvin Center Grand Ballroom

Michael Brudno: for annotations and identifying clinical terms, instead of learning the emdedding of the term, we can use a hierarchical embedding approach and look at how much value each term adds. This works well for T-SNE # RECOMB2019 pic.twitter.com/Is7W0wO6jl
Michael Brudno is talking about ontologies and how we can use NLP techniques like word embeddings to identify clinical terms in texts # RECOMB2019

Looks like awesome work. I’m curious how much of this would map to the decoy sequences? I’m aware quite at bit of the SGDP sequence ended up in there. Short of the next major release of GRCh we may want to add these as decoys too.
Used for what?

Great meeting many trainees at # RECOMB2019 Our lab at @ MIT and @ BroadInstitute is looking for talented computational postdocs to lead large-scale # genomics projects. At # Recomb2019, Sason presents multinomial mixture model for determining cancer mutational signatures. Does better than conventional NMF. Also, it’s “sticky” since each signature has a heightened chance to remain the same in terms of hidden variables

Hey @ recomb2019 attendees! If any of you want off the beaten path restaurant/coffee shop recommendations, tweet at me or @ BeccasBugs! See you all back for Martin Vingron’s talk at 1:45! # RECOMB2019

Amazing talk by @ rshermanjhu at # RECOMB2019 on her work on on assembly of a pan-genome, finding a large amount of sequence not represented in the human reference. Very exciting work (w @ StevenSalzberg1, and many others whom I will now try to find to follow on Twitter :))!
The pan-genome is still open. We need more methods / sequenced genomes to assemble novel sequences. # recomb2019 pic.twitter.com/r0e4BynS2f

In the # Recomb2019 Q&A, @ RShermanJHU argues that the linear increase suggests that graph genomes will prove unwieldy and that we should instead have multiple linear reference genomes CC @ StevenSalzberg1

Dr. Sherman’s excellent presentation on the human pangenome reminds us of the incredible diversity of the human genome. Unmapped reads very likely represent novel diversity. https://www.nature.com/articles/s41588-018-0273-y … @ StevenSalzberg1 Lab @ recomb2019
Hunting for the missing reference - @ rshermanjhu from @ StevenSalzberg1's lab talking about her work on why unaligned sequences in human sequencing studies are worth looking at # RECOMB2019

It will be good to keep in mind that there’s a lot that we’re missing and there’s probably a lot that we’re going to continue to miss as we study the human genome until our sampling expands a lot. - @ rshermanjhu # RECOMB2019 pic.twitter.com/9DCldjMazd

At # Recomb2019, @ RShermanJHU ends with the note that the “pan-genome is still open” - ie there’s seemingly a linear increase in number of new non-ref. sequences with number of individuals sub-sampled from the CAAPA cohort
By the way,this was exquisite work by @ rshermanjhu @ StevenSalzberg1 # RECOMB2019

Rachel Sherman @ rshermanjhu: It seems like reference genomes do not have systematic bias for any particular population and rather are not representing any populations fully . There are reads that don’t align to reference from all diverse populations. # RECOMB2019

A significant amount of human genomic information is lost/missed because of references sequences that are incomplete or representing poorly the human genetic diversity. Sherman et al studied them using assembly with # deepsequencing. # recomb2019 # humangenome # pangenome # africanpic.twitter.com/Pv9hUO613l – bei Lisner Auditorium
The reference genome does not describe any ethnicity well. Too many missing bits # recomb2019

Finally made it to # recomb2019, and fortunately arrived just in time for a highlight talk I was really looking forward to: Rachel Sherman talking now about Assembly of a pan-genome from deep sequencing of 910 humans of African descent". publication: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/30455414"

296.5 Mb non-human genome reference insertion sequences were found from 910 humans of African descent. The longest contig was 152,806 kb & found in many samples. 42,207 contigs aligned to the Chinese or Korean genomes! @ recomb2019 # RECOMB2019 pic.twitter.com/FgQVcL5hOQ
Rachel Sherman @ rshermanjhu is giving one of the best talks so far at # RECOMB2019 Interesting question, great story telling and nice slides!

Roughly 10% of the data from sequences are not being represented in the reference genomes and thus are ignored. Are these insertions functional? A lot of them are not only common but also in exon regions... # RECOMB2019 pic.twitter.com/riykGSE6YO
Rachel Sherman @ rshermanjhu talking about identifying sequences that don’t align using WGS data from african-descent population # RECOMB2019 pic.twitter.com/6leDaQ4xYf
Reference genome largely represents a SINGLE genome. Diversity representation? L # recomb2019
# til that the human genome reference is mostly comprised of a single individual from mixed ancestry. # RECOMB2019 @ recomb2019
Using Salmonella Genomes from GenomeTrakr as a benchmark a new mapper (bigbwt) # RECOMB2019 pic.twitter.com/BzKxDkEgIo

Using prefix-free parsing to compress repetitive strings (so smaller suffix array construction, etc) — anyone knows how the dictionary is created in the first place though? # RECOMB2019 pic.twitter.com/YRvJ3Q4gdQ
Alan Kuhnle is talking about r-index and how it solves the challenges with suffix arrays and FM index specially for strings with a lot of repetetive characters # RECOMB2019 pic.twitter.com/a0SLeg5xki
Good to see the genome sequencing cost slide for the 87th time at a talk (yes I do keep track) # recomb2019 pic.twitter.com/aavrCmCe3K

@ hp_ontology in keynote talk of @ recomb2019 pic.twitter.com/PVQBljMpHM

Using Hutchinson’s estimator, we can use matrix-vector multiplications instead of matrix-matrix multiplications for heritability studies (biobank) and thus speed up our computations # recomb2019 pic.twitter.com/pD9zOuLDiX
Ali Pazoki talking about heritability, how to calculate it and what are important parameters. For instance chromosome number is important for heritability of blood pressure # recomb2019

@ Alfons_Valencia kicking off the main conference # RECOMB2019 with his key-note on digital twins, stratified comorbidity networks and that having one disease can decrease chances of having another (e.g. AD & lung cancer) # precisionmedicine # networks # comorbidity

At # Recomb2019, @ Alfons_Valencia (working in the most beautiful supercomputing facility in the world!) describes his work on comorbidity & networks, using medical records ( @ recomb2019). Finds some diseases that are anti-correlated.
